SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: The presence of diabetes in pregnancy can result in substantial morbidity to both mother and baby if management is sub-optimal
AIMS: To assess the process of standards of preconception care (against the National Service Framework standards) of women attending the adult general diabetes clinics in a district general hospital
METHODS: Retrospective review of case notes of women aged 18-40 years attending the general diabetes clinics for annual review, over a period of 6 months
RESULTS: Seventy sets of notes were reviewed
The mean age of the patients was 32 years
Fifty-six patients had type-1 diabetes and 14 patients had type-2 diabetes
Mean duration of diabetes was 13 years
Eighty-six percent of the patients had blood pressure recordings documented
Documented evidence of home blood glucose monitoring was seen in 66% of the patients
Preconception counselling/contraception were discussed in 17 patients (25%)
Twenty-nine patients (41%) were on potentially teratogenic medications
Alcohol and smoking history was not documented in 91% and 61% of the patients, respectively

CONCLUSIONS: This retrospective assessment highlights that reproductive issues in an at risk population of women with diabetes are not included in routine management of diabetes care in outpatient clinics
